awd_titl_txt: LSAMP BD: Delaware State University / Greater Philadelphia Region Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (Philadelphia AMP)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (LSAMP) program assists universities and colleges in diversifying the STEM workforce through the development of highly competitive students from groups historically underrepresented in STEM disciplines:  African-Americans, Alaska Natives, American Indians, Hispanic Americans, Native Hawaiians, and Native Pacific Islanders.  The goal of the LSAMP Bridge to the Doctorate (BD) Activity is to increase the quantity and quality of STEM graduate students from underrepresented populations, with emphasis on Ph.D. matriculation and completion.  BD programs implemented in the nation's institutions of higher education contribute to addressing one of the objectives in NSF's 2018-2022 Strategic Plan, namely to "foster the growth of a more capable and diverse research workforce and advance the scientific and innovation skills of the Nation."  The vision of this grant is to provide a national model to produce underrepresented scientists and engineers with doctoral degrees in STEM.

Delaware State University (DSU) serves as host of a Bridge to the Doctorate (BD) project within the Greater Philadelphia Region Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation.  The DSU BD activity employs a multifaceted model that integrates research, education, and mentoring to address challenges underrepresented students face in doctoral programs.  As such this project seeks to (1) improve the overall graduate experience of STEM graduate students at DSU by increasing the depth and breadth of scientific and professional skills development activities and raising students' awareness of the full range of academic careers; and (2) to further enhance the administrative structure and support to facilitate the long-term sustainability of DSU's graduate programs.  The program components are executed via academic coursework for scientific and technical competency that prepares BD students for the doctoral degree qualifying and candidacy examinations; substantive cutting-edge laboratory research experiences beginning in the first-year to expose fellows to research that can form the basis for their doctoral dissertation; professional development experiences such as workshops, seminars and/or conferences to help students to develop the ancillary skills needed for personal and professional success; facilitated interaction with faculty and peers to fully integrate students into research groups; opportunities for students to present their research nationally and/or internationally to promote their engagement with the larger scientific and technical community; and opportunities for student reflection, and the development of coping skills to contextualize the pressures and challenges associated with graduate study.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
Drexel University, as a representative of the Greater Philadelphia Region Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (Philadelphia AMP), received funding from the National Science Foundation to host a Bridge to the Doctorate (BD) Cohort XVI project at Delaware State University (DSU) for students from underrepresented minority groups, mainly African Americans, Hispanics, Native Americans, and Native Hawaiians / Pacific Islanders. The Philadelphia AMP represents a diverse alliance of nine institutions consisting of public and private, 2- and 4-year research and non-research, Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) and majority institutions. 

The goals of the BD Cohort XVI project were to: (1) increase the number of underrepresented minority students who enter STEM graduate programs at DSU and successfully graduate with Master's degrees; and 2) increase the capacity of the STEM graduate programs at DSU to support diverse students to graduate with doctoral degrees, either directly in its doctoral programs, or by completing a Master's degree and bridging to a doctoral program at another institution.

The BD XVI project placed special emphasis on programming that focused on the following:

  • Academic coursework for scientific and technical competency that prepared BD fellows for the doctoral degree qualifying and candidacy examinations;
  • Substantive cutting-edge laboratory research experiences beginning in the first year to expose fellows to research that could form the basis for their doctoral studies;
  • Professional development experiences such as workshops, seminars and/or conferences to help students to develop the ancillary skills needed for personal and professional success;
  • Facilitated interaction with faculty and peers to fully integrate students into research groups;
  • Opportunities for fellows to present their research to promote their engagement with the larger scientific and technical community.

As a direct result of the latter approach, ten (10) of the twelve (12) BD fellows (or 83%) recruited for program participation were retained. Of the retained BD fellows, of the eight (8) fellows who matriculated into MS programs, five (5) fellows (or 62.5%) have graduated and one fellow (1) is still progressing toward her degree completion. Of the four (4) BD fellows who matriculated directly into one of DSU's PhD programs, one (1) fellow was awarded his PhD degree in Applied Chemistry in May 2022 and presently is employed as a Visiting Assistant Professor, Department of Chemistry at DSU with a research focus in Crohn's Disease;  the other three (3) fellows who are majoring in Applied Chemistry, Optics / Optical Sciences, and Neuroscience, respectively, remain in good academic standing making progress toward their PhD degree completion. In addition, one (1) Molecular and Cell Neuroscience MS degree recipient has also transitioned to doctoral study at Mississippi State University where he is pursuing a PhD degree in Kinesiology and Exercise Science, and is currently a scholar in both the Southern Regional Education Board's (SREB) Harold Grier's Scholar's Program and the University of Mississippi Medical Center's (UMMC) Graduate Training Program which is focused on serving underrepresented populations in the Jackson, Mississippi area. His current research in the Neuromechanics Lab involves reducing the risk of lower extremity injuries in an athletic population by examining the neuromechanical factors which are most prevalent in distal lower extremity injuries.

In addition, the External Evaluator's findings concluded that the BD project was conducted in an effective and efficient manner which contributed to the retention and progression of the BD fellows, and was recommended as a model for replication for others due to its design, effectiveness and overall success. It was indicated that the most telling data was that of the BD fellows, their success and graduation from the project and the institutional and faculty commitment to the BD fellows' achievement, as well as the fact that the BD project was able to maintain its standard of excellence throughout the COVID-19 pandemic which changed the world. Despite the pandemic, DSU was still able to afford BD fellows opportunities, and the BD fellows continued to be supported and performed within their respective majors.

Specifically, the BD Cohort XVI project worked: a) to improve the overall graduate experience of STEM graduate students at DSU by increasing the depth and breadth of scientific and professional skills development activities and raising students' awareness of the full range of academic careers; and b) to further enhance the administrative structure and support to facilitate the long-term sustainability of DSU's graduate programs. The evaluation findings will also continue to be used to inform DSU graduate school policies and programming, as well as to expand the Alliance's best practice recommendations for its implementation of future BD Cohorts.
